questions.text: All of the following are sources of phosphate taking part in energy capture, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Beta oxidation of fatty acids is not the source of phosphate in ATP production

  • Produces NADH and FADH2, which enter the ETC to generate ATP indirectly
  • No direct Pi transfer to ADP occurs in this pathway
  • ATP generation is oxidative and downstream, not direct
  • ATP acts as the energy currency of the cell
  • The high group transfer potential of ATP enables it to act as a donor of high-energy phosphate to form many compounds.
  • Likewise, with the necessary enzymes, ADP can accept phosphate groups to form ATP from some compounds.
  • In effect, an ATP/ADP cycle connects those processes that generate high-energy phosphate to those processes that utilize high-energy phosphate, continuously consuming and regenerating ATP.
  • There are three major sources in which phosphate takes part in energy conservation or energy capture

Explanation of Other Options:

Oxidative phosphorylation(Option A): Oxidative phosphorylation is the greatest quantitative source of high-energy phosphate in aerobic organisms. ATP is generated in the mitochondrial matrix as O2 is reduced to H2O by electrons passing down the respiratory chain.

Glycolysis(Option B): Glycolysis. A net formation of two high-energy phosphates results from the formation of lactate from one molecule of glucose, generated in two reactions catalyzed by phosphoglycerate kinase and pyruvate kinase, respectively.

TCA Cycle(Option C): The citric acid cycle. One high-energy phosphate is generated directly in the cycle at the succinate thiokinase step.

questions.text: Which of the following is a high-energy compound?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • ACP is a central molecule in fatty acid synthesis.
  • It carries acyl groups via a high-energy thioester bond (similar to CoA).
  • This thioester linkage is a high-energy bond, making ACP a high-energy compound in metabolic terms.
  • High-energy compounds are those that contain energy-rich bonds. They are present in all living cells, participating in the energy accumulation and conversion processes.

They include,

  1. ATP (Adenosine triphosphate)
  2. Acyl carrier protein (Option B)
  3. S - adenosylmethionine (active methionine),
  4. Thiol esters involving coenzyme A (eg, acetyl-CoA),
  5. Amino acid esters involved in protein synthesis,
  6. Uridine diphosphate glucose (UDPGlc),
  7. 5-phosphoribosyl-1-pyrophosphate (PRPP).

Explanation of Other Options:

Fatty acid(Option A): Fatty acids are not considered high-energy compounds as they do not contain energy-rich bonds. But they can produce energy through their breakdown (beta oxidation). One molecule of Palmitic acid (16C, saturated fatty acid), when completely broken down (by beta oxidation & electron transport chain), will produce a net of 106 ATPs. Similarly, one molecule of Stearic acid (18C, saturated fatty acid) will produce a net of 120 ATPs.

Glucose(Option C): Glucose is not considered a high-energy compound as it does not contain energy-rich bonds. Glucose can produce energy through its breakdown. One molecule of glucose (6C, aldohexose), when completely broken down into 6 CO2 (by glycolysis, TCA cycle & electron transport chain), will produce a net of 32 ATPs.

Glycerol(Option D): Glycerol is also not a high-energy compound.

questions.text: A molecule carrying high-energy electrons generated during the pentose phosphate pathway is oxidized. How many molecules of ATP are synthesized per molecule of this electron carrier when it enters the mitochondrial electron transport chain?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pentose Phosphate Pathway (PPP) produces NADPH. NADPH is never used to produce ATP in oxidative phosphorylation; instead, it is used for reductive biosynthesis of many compounds.

  • NADPH does not feed into the mitochondrial ETC.
  • It is used exclusively in cytosolic anabolic and protective reactions.
  • So, no ATP is generated from NADPH via oxidative phosphorylation.

NADPH-Linked Pathways

Explanation of Other Options:

1.5(Option B): The oxidation of one molecule of FADH2 in oxidative phosphorylation produces 1.5 ATPs.

2.5(Option C): The oxidation of one molecule of NADH in oxidative phosphorylation produces 2.5 ATPs.

3(Option D): It was believed that the oxidation of one molecule of NADH in oxidative phosphorylation produces 3 ATPs earlier, but recently it has been corrected to 2.5.

questions.text: Which of the following is acting as a phosphagen in vertebrate skeletal muscle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Creatine phosphate acts as a phosphagen in vertebrate skeletal muscle

  • Phosphagens are high-energy storage molecules that act as rapid ATP buffers in muscle and nerve tissues - they donate phosphate groups to ADP to regenerate ATP during short bursts of intense activity. Phosphagens act as storage forms of group transfer potential and include creatine phosphate, which occurs in vertebrate skeletal muscle, heart, spermatozoa, and brain, and arginine phosphate, which occurs in invertebrate muscle.

Explanation of Other Options:

Arginine phosphate(Option B): Arginine phosphate acts as a phosphagen in invertebrate muscle.

Glucose 6-phosphate and Fructose 6-phosphate (Option C & Option D): Glucose 6-phosphate and fructose 6-phosphate do not act as Phosphagens.
